utterances: What am I going to - I'm going to be celebrating with Mr. Obama.
(Soundbite of laughter)
You're going to watch on TV?
I'm going to go find a TV somewhere, yes, and watch the TV, yes, definitely.
Well, Jean Wilson, thanks so much.
Congratulations.
Thank you.
Jean Wilson, executive director of United Peace Relief Detroit, where today, she cooked some chilli and fed some of Detroit's homeless.
What did you do to mark Martin Luther King Day this year?
800-989-8255, email is talk@npr.org, and let's begin with Father Motet(ph), is that right?
Right.
In Davenport, Iowa.
Go ahead, please.
Right.
Well, we're just returning from a two-day conference in Des Moines in Iowa's statewide meeting on social action.
Been doing this for years, we usually hold it over this weekend, and we emphasize the two feet of social justice.
First foot is charity, where we do trying to (unintelligible) emergencies, and secondly, we move on to justice, trying to get to the causes of poverty.
And we have people from all over the state come, and we do training.
We have community organizing training and other kinds of training and people reporting on what they're doing around the state.
Well, Davenport, where you're calling from, was devastated by floods earlier - well, last year.
Well, it was more Iowa City and Cedar Rapids.
They had it worse than we did.
OK.
Yeah, they did.
And why this weekend?
This weekend - well, because it's an appropriate time to just talk about justice on this weekend.
And we also - some of us were at the scene when Martin Luther King gave the I Have A Dream speech.
Back 1963.
Were you there?
'63, we were there up front, and then he came to Davenport in 1965 to receive the Prosper, Cherish Peace, and Freedom award, and we have a recording of that speech, too, with some of the same themes.
And also, I think it's important because Iowa was the first one to give Obama his start.
Indeed, it did, January 3rd last year, the Iowa caucuses.
That's right, 97 percent white, and we nominated an African-American candidate.
Well, father, thank you, and I hope you have safe travels today.
Yes.
Thank you.
Bye-bye.
Now, let's see if we can go next to - this is Daniel, Daniel with us from St. Louis.
Yes.
How are you doing?
Very well.
Thank you.
What are you doing today?
I'm already finished today.
I'm going to go to a celebration later.
I got two friends of mine, and we went to a part of town that they probably would not have gone to, and we helped out with a food bank.
And what were you doing specifically?
They had collected cans from - it's just different kinds of cans.
So we helped them separate it into soups, vegetables, and fruit.
It was really nice.
It was a Jewish Food Bank, and I'm Jewish, and one of my friends is half, and the other one is not.
And it was really - it was really nice bringing them into, you know, just a different - differing religions and cultures together to help out on this day.
And this day in particular, are you going to be back another day to help again?
Probably not to this place because I'm leaving the country in a month, but I've been serving this month.
Actually, I've been going to a retirement community and helping the members use computers.
So I've already been doing some service, and when I get back into the country in July, I'll probably do something similar.
Daniel, thanks very much.
Where are you going?
I'm going to Israel.
OK.
Well, have a great trip.
Thank you very much.
Interesting.
Well, it's a serious thing for businesses to think about.
Indeed.
Appreciate it.
Here's an email from Sandra in Salt Lake City.
I'm a hospice nurse, and I am continuing to do my normal service.
Let's get Caroline on the line.
Caroline - well, it says Chuckie on the line - I suspect it's Truckee, California.
Yes, it is.
Go ahead, please.
Hi there.

My children and I live in a really privileged town in northern California, it's a mountain town, a resort town, and we woke up this morning, and I said to my girls, it's, you know Barack Obama has asked us to do something today, and what are we going to do?
We decided to go to a senior center and talk to some women who - all the elderly women who needed to chat.
But I think the most profound part of the day was when my nine-year-old daughter said, mommy, it's so nice that Barack Obama has asked us to do something today.
And I just looked at her, and I thought, how profound that here we are.
He's not quite president yet, but we are doing what he's asking us to do, and it's not just he that is feeling so good about it, but we are feeling so good about it.
And will you do it again?
Absolutely.
We've created quite a culture in our family around Barack Obama, and we've - the girls and I have done a lot of fundraising.

They made stationeries with pieces of his speeches, and we sold that for his campaign, and we - although, ironically, we live in a place that doesn't need us as much as we'd like it to, we will always do something, and we give thanks that Barack Obama has inspired us to get back in the game.
Caroline, thanks for the call.
Have a great day.
Thank you.
Bye-bye.
Bye-bye.
And let's go now to Becky.
Becky is calling from Sacramento.
Yes, hi.
Hi.
How are you today?
Good.
I just wanted to say that my sisters and I have been making hand-made cards for the troops.
We started last night.
It's kind of our service project.
And when you say hand-made cards, what do they say?
What do they look like?
